repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This PR would create a new Lua module called 'versioncheck.lua'.

Closes #21431

Wanted to see if I'm on the right track here, and also to plea for help with testing this. I've left the skeleton of the testing there, if someone would like to pick it up or explain how I would go about testing this module, I'd be thrilled. I've tried a few different ways, based on what other runtime modules like secure and editorconfig do, but I just don't understand busted well enough and the how, when, and why of Neovim functional testing (also probably doesn't help that I'm not a dev). Rather than just give up completely, I thought I'd just throw this up here if someone wants to take it over instead of walking me through it that's totally fine!

comment_data.body: `CursorHold` probably isn't right for this. Why not `VimEnter`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,23 @@
+if vim.g.loaded_versioncheck ~= nil then
+  return
+end
+vim.g.loaded_versioncheck = true
+
+-- detect non-interactive startups
+if vim.tbl_contains(vim.v.argv, '-l') then
+  return
+end
+
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= true then
+  return
+end
+
+local augroup = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('versioncheck', {})
+
+vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('CursorHold', {

comment_data.body: Just because it was mentioned in the original issue. I think the idea is we try to avoid disrupting any user startup routine by delaying it, this is just one solution. I'll have a look at VimEnter too. Now I wonder if we can rely on UIEnter to avoid the check for non-interactive startup?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,23 @@
+if vim.g.loaded_versioncheck ~= nil then
+  return
+end
+vim.g.loaded_versioncheck = true
+
+-- detect non-interactive startups
+if vim.tbl_contains(vim.v.argv, '-l') then
+  return
+end
+
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= true then
+  return
+end
+
+local augroup = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('versioncheck', {})
+
+vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('CursorHold', {

comment_data.body:
want see if we can avoid saying 'we now...' in every single news item

```suggestion
• Nvim shows news.txt on startup if it is a prerelease that has news since the previous build.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,6 +40,8 @@ The following new APIs or features were added.
   iterators |luaref-in|.
 
 • Added |vim.keycode()| for translating keycodes in a string.
+• We now offer to show detected to news.txt (prerelease

comment_data.body: Instead of using a file, how about storing a flag in shada. If shada is disabled/empty (`nvim -n`), just skip the "show news" step.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,70 @@
+local M = {}
+
+---@private
+--- Writes runtime/doc/news.txt to stdpath('state')/news.txt
+local function _write_news_to_cache()
+  local cached_news = io.open(vim.fn.stdpath('state') .. '/news.txt', 'w+')

comment_data.body:
we discussed in some other PR a new convention (example: `:help g:editorconfig`). No more of this `loaded_` thing in Lua plugins. Instead, use the plugin name as a top-level namespace. 

Something like `vim.g.versioncheck`, which is a dict. If it's `false`, that means skip loading. Else, the plugin uses it as a dict to store plugin-specific options (if any).
great, will do! helps avoid cases I was thinking of covering where you could set `let g:loaded_versioncheck = 0` (which is still truthy in lua when converted).

Not sure I understand, could you elaborate some more on that? here's how I thought about it:

We fire a 'check for news' function on CursorHold event, provided the module:

1.  hasn't been disabled (either by `vim.g.versioncheck = false`, or 
2. non-interactive session detected (e.g., `nvim -l`), or 
3. `vim.version()` has `prerelease = true`. 

'check for news' first checks if shada stored `NVIM_VERSION` exists: if it doesn't we want to store the current `vim.version()` value in it, write the current `runtime/doc/news.txt` file to `stdpath('state')..'news.txt'` and finish. I think this is where you are saying we _shouldn't_ just blindly save the current news.txt file to the stdpath('state')?

The option to show the news in the current implementation doesn't occur if `vim.g.NVIM_VERSION` doesn't exist, you're only given the option to see a diff if `NVIM_VERSION` shada does exist and it's older than current session `vim.version()` (or the corner case where the versions match, but there's somehow a different in byte size between the cached news.txt in stdpath('state') and the the runtime/doc/news.txt file).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,70 @@
+local M = {}
+
+---@private
+--- Writes runtime/doc/news.txt to stdpath('state')/news.txt
+local function _write_news_to_cache()
+  local cached_news = io.open(vim.fn.stdpath('state') .. '/news.txt', 'w+')

comment_regular_data.body:
If this opinion is outside of this PR, fell free to ignore this.

I think this is greatly useful mechanism of plugin authors to announce plugin changes for users.

I had been think similar mechanism on my plugin related works but I avoid to save cache data for the user's disk on un-officual way.

> If this opinion is outside of this PR, fell free to ignore this.
> 
> I think this is greatly useful mechanism of plugin authors to announce plugin changes for users.
> 
> I had been think similar mechanism on my plugin related works but I avoid to save cache data for the user's disk on un-officual way.

@hrsh7th  I mean, I'd love that as well, but I think it's outside of the scope of this PR. If we can get this working ok, I don't see any reason why someone couldn't think about refactoring/extending it into a general mechanism later if wanted.

NOTE: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/23687 is currently causing issues with comparisons, may work around by just extracting from `vim.version()` what is really needed to compare cached vs current `vim.g.NVIM_VERSION`.

title: feat(runtime): offer to show news.txt diff on startup
